repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body: What is a "user-defined function"?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -41,6 +41,34 @@ All header files should start with `#pragma once` to prevent multiple inclusion.
         #pragma once
 <
 
+Headers system ~
+
+Neovim has uses two types of headers. There are "normal" headers and "defs"
+headers. Typically, each normal header will have a corresponding defs header,
+e.g. fileio.h and fileio_defs.h. This distinction is done to minimize
+recompilation of header files on change. Use the following rules to decide
+where to put what:
+
+- All non-symbols shall be moved to _defs.h:
+  - macros, i.e. `#define`.
+    - EXCEPTION: if the macro calls a user-defined function, then it needs to

comment_data.body: Note: moving an enum constant (or `#define`d constant) to a _defs cannot lead to less recompilation on change if it can only be used by the callers of a specific function (ref #26622), as users of the enum constant must have already included the header for the function.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -41,6 +41,34 @@ All header files should start with `#pragma once` to prevent multiple inclusion.
         #pragma once
 <
 
+Headers system ~
+
+Neovim has uses two types of headers. There are "normal" headers and "defs"
+headers. Typically, each normal header will have a corresponding defs header,
+e.g. fileio.h and fileio_defs.h. This distinction is done to minimize
+recompilation of header files on change. Use the following rules to decide
+where to put what:
+
+- All non-symbols shall be moved to _defs.h:
+  - macros, i.e. `#define`.
+    - EXCEPTION: if the macro calls a function from a non-system header, then
+      it needs to be moved to a normal header.
+  - static inline functions, but only if its function declaration has a
+    REAL_FATTR_ALWAYS_INLINE attribute.
+  - typedefs
+  - structs
+  - enum constants

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -41,6 +41,34 @@ All header files should start with `#pragma once` to prevent multiple inclusion.
         #pragma once
 <
 
+Headers system ~
+
+Nvim has uses two types of headers. There are "normal" headers and "defs"
+headers. Typically, each normal header will have a corresponding defs header,
+e.g. fileio.h and fileio_defs.h. This distinction is done to minimize
+recompilation of header files on change. Use the following rules to decide
+where to put what:
+
+- All non-symbols shall be moved to _defs.h:
+  - macros, i.e. `#define`.
+    - EXCEPTION: if the macro calls a function from a non-system header, then
+      it needs to be moved to a normal header.
+  - static inline functions, but only if its function declaration has a
+    REAL_FATTR_ALWAYS_INLINE attribute.
+  - typedefs
+  - structs
+  - enum constants
+
+All symbols shall be moved to regular .h:
+  - regular function declarations
+  - `extern` variables (including the `EXTERN` macro)
+
+All headers are allowed to include only defs headers, system headers and
+generated declarations, regardless of whether they are defs headers or regular
+headers.
+
+c files are expected to include both _defs.h and regular headers, regular

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
- All symbols should be moved to normal headers.
```
Or "must"? (It's _really_ helpful to always stick to the common terminology "can" vs. "should" vs. "must".)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -41,6 +41,43 @@ All header files should start with `#pragma once` to prevent multiple inclusion.
         #pragma once
 <
 
+Headers system ~
+
+Nvim has uses two types of headers. There are "normal" headers and "defs"
+headers. Typically, each normal header will have a corresponding defs header,
+e.g. fileio.h and fileio_defs.h. This distinction is done to minimize
+recompilation on change. The goal is to achieve the following setup:
+
+All headers (defs and normal) are allowed to include only defs headers, system
+headers and generated declarations. In other words, headers should never
+include normal headers.
+
+.c files can include all headers, normal headers only if they need symbols and
+not types.
+
+Use the following guideline to determine where to put what:
+
+Symbols:
+  - regular function declarations
+  - `extern` variables (including the `EXTERN` macro)
+
+Non-symbols:
+  - macros, i.e. `#define`.
+  - static inline functions, but only if its function declaration has a
+    `REAL_FATTR_ALWAYS_INLINE` attribute.
+  - typedefs
+  - structs
+  - enums
+
+
+â€¢ All symbols shall be moved to normal headers.

```suggestion
to ensure headers only include defs headers. Conversely, non-symbols used
by only a single header should be moved to that header.
```

I think it's a little weird to begin a sentence with punctuation. Maybe this is just me, but if others agree, I suggest this instead:

```suggestion
- Source (.c) files may include all headers, but should only include normal headers if they need symbols and
```

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -41,6 +41,43 @@ All header files should start with `#pragma once` to prevent multiple inclusion.
         #pragma once
 <
 
+Headers system ~
+
+Nvim has uses two types of headers. There are "normal" headers and "defs"
+headers. Typically, each normal header will have a corresponding defs header,
+e.g. `fileio.h` and `fileio_defs.h`. This distinction is done to minimize
+recompilation on change. The goal is to achieve the following setup:
+
+- All headers (defs and normal) are allowed to include only defs headers, system
+headers and generated declarations. In other words, headers should never
+include normal headers.
+
+- .c files can include all headers but normal headers only if they need symbols and
+not types.
+
+Use the following guideline to determine what to put where:
+
+Symbols:
+  - regular function declarations
+  - `extern` variables (including the `EXTERN` macro)
+
+Non-symbols:
+  - macros, i.e. `#define`.
+  - static inline functions, but only if its function declaration has a
+    `REAL_FATTR_ALWAYS_INLINE` attribute.
+  - typedefs
+  - structs
+  - enums
+
+
+- All symbols must be moved to normal headers.
+
+- Non-symbols used by multiple headers should be moved to defs headers. This is
+to ensure headers only include defs headers. Conversely, non-symbols used
+by only a single header should be moved to that header.

comment_data.body:

```suggestion
  headers, and generated declarations. In other words, headers must not
  include normal headers.
```

+headers, and generated declarations. In other words, headers must not
+include normal headers.

@@ -41,6 +41,43 @@ All header files should start with `#pragma once` to prevent multiple inclusion.
         #pragma once
 <
 
+Headers system ~
+
+Nvim uses two types of headers. There are "normal" headers and "defs"
+headers. Typically, each normal header will have a corresponding defs header,
+e.g. `fileio.h` and `fileio_defs.h`. This distinction is done to minimize
+recompilation on change. The goal is to achieve the following:
+
+- All headers (defs and normal) must include only defs headers, system
+headers, and generated declarations. In other words, headers must not
+include normal headers.
+
+- Source (.c) files may include all headers, but should only include normal headers if they need symbols and
+not types.

comment_data.body: This line should be wrapped
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -41,6 +41,43 @@ All header files should start with `#pragma once` to prevent multiple inclusion.
         #pragma once
 <
 
+Headers system ~
+
+Nvim uses two types of headers. There are "normal" headers and "defs"
+headers. Typically, each normal header will have a corresponding defs header,
+e.g. `fileio.h` and `fileio_defs.h`. This distinction is done to minimize
+recompilation on change. The goal is to achieve the following:
+
+- All headers (defs and normal) must include only defs headers, system
+  headers, and generated declarations. In other words, headers must not
+  include normal headers.
+
+- Source (.c) files may include all headers, but should only include normal headers if they need symbols and
+  not types.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim
